natural solution: We can re-write the given expression as $(16 \times 17 \times 18)^{17} \times 17 \times 18^2$. First, we find the units digit of $(16 \times 17 \times 18)^{17}$. The units digit of $16 \times 17 \times 18$ is that of $6 \times 7 \times 8,$ or that of $2 \times 8$, or $6$.
When raised to any perfect power, a positive integer ending in $6$ will still end in $6$, so $(16 \times 17 \times 18)^{17}$ has a units digit of $6$.
Now, we need to find the units digit of $6 \times 17 \times 18^2$, or the units digit of $2 \times 18^2$, which is $\boxed{8}$.

fixes n :: nat

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y z :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"

shows  "a mod 10 = 0"
